title: Corrections: March 21, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 21, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about voters who want to hear former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. speak more about climate change misidentified the group that Collin O’Mara leads. It is the National Wildlife Federation, not the National Wildlife Foundation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
title: Biden Takes Charge as Coronavirus Spreads: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Joe Biden won all three states that held primary contests on Tuesday, forcing Bernie Sanders to reassess the future of his campaign in a race that has been upended by a public health crisis.
content: With the coronavirus pandemic front of mind, electoral politics may feel like a distant concern. Yet the Democratic primary is pressing on, even as the public health crisis has hugely altered it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauretta Charlton
title: A Virus Both Divides Us, and Brings Us Together
description: As the coronavirus spreads across the world, thinking seriously about cultural insensitivity feels more important than ever.
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Freezers Sell Out as Consumers Stock Up
description: As the coronavirus pandemic continues, people are preparing to hunker down for weeks or longer.
content: The calls come every five minutes, Chris Rouse said, all asking for the same thing: a small chest freezer. That’s a problem for Mr. Rouse, an appliance salesman in the Town of Wallkill, N.Y. He has no more to sell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Betty Williams, Peace Laureate From Northern Ireland, Dies at 76
description: She and Mairead Corrigan shared the 1976 Nobel Prize for galvanizing a mass movement to protest sectarian violence during the time known as the Troubles.
content: DUBLIN — Betty Williams, a grass-roots activist who shared the 1976 Nobel Peace Prize as a founder of a protest movement that mobilized tens of thousands of people to demand an end to the sectarian violence in Northern Ireland known as the Troubles, died on Tuesday. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: Planning a Wedding at Home? Here Are a Few Things to Consider
description: Whether your plans are last-minute because of the coronavirus outbreak, or you’ve always wanted intimate nuptials in your backyard, these tips can help.
content: While many couples around the world are canceling or postponing their weddings because of the coronavirus pandemic, some are scaling down their plans and getting married at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, Mitch Smith, Karen Yourish and Sarah Almukhtar
title: Watch How the Coronavirus Spread Across the United States
description: It’s been two months since the first confirmed case was reported in the United States. As testing expanded and the virus spread, the number of new cases has multiplied at a rapid pace.
content: It’s been two months since the first confirmed case was reported in the United States. As testing expanded and the virus spread, the number of new cases has multiplied at a rapid pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Americans Coping With the Coronavirus Are Clogging Toilets
description: Sewage systems and toilets are backing up as consumers clean their homes with disinfectant wipes and turn to paper towels, napkins and baby wipes to cope with the lack of toilet paper.
content: Many Americans seem to be following the recommendations of public health officials to clean and sterilize countertops, doorknobs, faucets and other frequently touched surfaces in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Coronavirus Has Disrupted My Life
description: We asked readers how they are coping. They wrote about the emotional and financial hardships, the effect on relationships, and how they are trying to find silver linings in such dire times.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Thank God the Doctor Is In
description: Peeking out our windows, we see America shriveling.
content: WASHINGTON — It’s not easy being a national treasure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Coronavirus Has Disrupted My Life
description: We asked readers how they are coping. They wrote about the emotional and financial hardships, the effect on relationships, and how they are trying to find silver linings in such dire times.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Thank God the Doctor Is In
description: Peeking out our windows, we see America shriveling.
content: WASHINGTON — It’s not easy being a national treasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Kelly
title: I Spent a Year in Space, and I Have Tips on Isolation to Share
description: Take it from someone who couldn’t: Go outside.
content: Being stuck at home can be challenging. When I lived on the International Space Station for nearly a year, it wasn’t easy. When I went to sleep, I was at work. When I woke up, I was still at work. Flying in space is probably the only job you absolutely cannot quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Google Gives Cover to Trump’s Lies
description: If one of the most powerful tech companies can’t call out the president’s dishonesty, who can?
content: President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic has been a case study in a management style marked by falsehoods and intimidation. Rather than risk inviting his ire, subordinates and fellow Republicans covered for him as he delayed a coordinated response to the coronavirus and it felled nearly 200 Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: 20 Seconds That Make These Dreary Times Go Faster
description: We needed a different song to wash our hands by. So I reached out to a pro.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Coronavirus Compounds Financial Concerns in Women’s Sports
description: Paychecks and sponsor deals were already much smaller for female athletes. Postponements and cancellations have added further uncertainty about their wages: “This whole situation is just so scary.”
content: For Isabelle Harrison, the coronavirus wake-up call came when she rushed to her grocery store in Bologna, Italy, to find the shelves cleaned out of pasta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Where Are All the Masks?
description: In the United States, there is a shortage of medical equipment. What’s going on?
content: As the heath care system strains to accommodate the unprecedented challenge of the coronavirus outbreak, many medical professionals on the front lines do not have adequate protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: How It All Came Apart for Bernie Sanders
description: The Sanders campaign appeared on the brink of a commanding lead in the Democratic race. But a series of fateful decisions and internal divisions have left him all but vanquished.
content: In mid-January, a few weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Senator Bernie Sanders’s pollster offered a stark prognosis for the campaign: Mr. Sanders was on track to finish strong in the first three nominating states, but Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s powerful support from older African-Americans could make him a resilient foe in South Carolina and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: The Coronavirus’s Rampage Through a Suburban Nursing Home
description: Two-thirds of Life Care Center’s residents and 47 of its workers fell ill. Thirty-five people died. We investigated what went wrong.
content: KIRKLAND, Wash. — Loretta Rapp, 79, was easy to spot as she zipped through the Life Care Center nursing home in her electric wheelchair, dressed in one of her bright muumuus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: Coming to a Country Near You: A Russian Nuclear Power Plant
description: A Russian state company is financing and building reactors across the world, reaping for Moscow both profits and geopolitical influence.
content: ASTRAVETS, Belarus — Rising from the former potato and wheat fields of a collective farm, huge towers of concrete beckon to one of Europe’s poorest countries with the promise of cheap, plentiful supplies of electricity for generations to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Commanding the Situation
description: Stuck inside on a Saturday? Damon Gulczynski drops in with a diversion.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Longtime solvers will be glad to see Damon Gulczynski back on a weekend; it’s been about a year and a half, and he’s been a prolific constructor for The Times and a frequent contributor of tough stuff, which this puzzle certainly is.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: $1 Trillion Stimulus Spurs Lobbying Gold Rush
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 21, 2020.
content: “The only industry that hasn’t been slowed down by the virus is the lobbying industry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1895: London Stockbrokers Appear in Court
description: Four men were accused of causing a commotion in the British capital.
content: [BY THE HERALD’S SPECIAL WIRE.] LONDON, March 21. — The determination of the police to put down stock dealing in Throgmorton-street kept the city in a state of excitement yesterday, as up to the present the operations of outside brokers have been conducted under the supervision and control of the police.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: Alone Together
description: On this special episode, we hear how people all over the world are facing the crisis — by coming together on the internet.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Iran Releases French Academic in a Prisoner Swap
description: Roland Marchal has been imprisoned in Iran since June on national security charges. France reportedly freed an Iranian engineer wanted in the United States over alleged sanctions violations.
content: PARIS — Iran has released the French academic Roland Marchal, an official in the French president’s office said on Saturday, as part of a prisoner swap agreement with France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: ‘Terrified’ Package Delivery Employees Are Going to Work Sick
description: Truckers and warehouse workers at UPS and FedEx feel they have no choice but to keep showing up, even with coronavirus-like symptoms.
content: Hour after hour, day after day, the packages keep arriving: food, medicine, clothes, toys and a million other items brought to the doorsteps and building lobbies of Americans who are hunkering down as the coronavirus sweeps the land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Here’s What Calling in the National Guard Means
description: The coronavirus outbreak has prompted dozens of governors to activate the National Guard. The sight of troops has stoked fears of a military-enforced quarantine, but the orders have been more mundane.
content: In Puerto Rico, they are taking passengers’ temperatures at the island’s largest airport. In Wisconsin, they escorted cruise ship passengers back to their houses for quarantine. In Florida, they are swabbing people’s noses near Miami to test for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Bring Your ‘A’ Game
description: Brendan Emmett Quigley makes the grade with this Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Brendan Emmett Quigley is in the pantheon of great veteran Times constructors, and today’s grid is absorbing and clever. I found it plenty crunchy — it took two sittings to completely finish — but bright and self-assured in a welcoming way. I hope nobody gave up on it before figuring out its fun gimmick. If you were on the verge, join us and prepare to be enlightened!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Buskirk
title: Coronavirus Gives Trump a Chance to Make Good on His Promises
description: His vision of how to wield American power has a lot going for it in a crisis like this one.
content: The coronavirus guarantees that for the foreseeable future President Trump will be right where he likes to be: front and center, with the spotlight squarely on him. His likely Democratic challenger, Joe Biden, is an afterthought as the nation grapples with a challenge to public health and the devastating fallout that comes from shutting down large portions of the economy and ordering millions of people to stay home under almost all circumstances as has been done in California, New York and other hard-hit states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Don’t Put More People in New York’s Jails During a Pandemic
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the State Legislature can save lives by resisting calls to roll back criminal justice reforms.
content: The last thing New York needs right now, as it fights a deadly pandemic, is more people in jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh, Matt Futterman, Tariq Panja and Motoko Rich
title: An Olympic Showdown: The Rising Clamor to Postpone the Tokyo Summer Games
description: Athletes and sports organizations are pushing back against the I.O.C.’s insistence that the Games go on this summer despite the coronavirus pandemic.
content: On July 24, as far as the organizers of the Olympics are still concerned, thousands of athletes will march as scheduled into the national stadium in Tokyo for the opening ceremony of the biggest sporting event on the planet. The Summer Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.Y. Weighs Four Temporary Hospitals Sites, Including Javits Center
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo said one million face masks were being sent to hospitals in New York City and another 500,000 to Long Island.
content: With coronavirus threatening to overwhelm New York hospitals, state officials are considering turning landmark locations like the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center into makeshift hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: The Hardest Questions Doctors May Face: Who Will Be Saved? Who Won’t?
description: As coronavirus infections explode in the U.S., hospitals could be forced to make harrowing choices if pushed to the brink. Planning is already underway.
content: The medical director of the intensive care unit had to choose which patients’ lives would be supported by ventilators and other equipment. Hurricane Sandy was bearing down on Bellevue Hospital in New York City in 2012, and the main generators were about to fail. Dr. Laura Evans would be left with only six power outlets for the unit’s 50 patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Top U.S. Intelligence Official Taps New Counterterrorism Chief
description: Lora Shiao will be the new acting director for the National Counterterrorism Center amid a broader reshuffling of top intelligences aides and expected personnel cutbacks
content: WASHINGTON — Lora Shiao, a career American intelligence officer, will be the next acting director of the National Counterterrorism Center, the government’s central clearinghouse for intelligence on terrorist threats, Trump administration officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
title: Joe Biden’s Campaign Was Cash Poor. He Seized Control of the Nomination Anyway.
description: New figures show just how big a financial hole the former vice president was in before he pulled off a remarkable turnaround in the Democratic race.
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has taken command of the Democratic primary for president despite running on a shoestring budget in a contest where Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised more money in February alone, $47.6 million, than Mr. Biden had spent in his previous five months combined, new federal records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How the Defense Production Act Could Yield More Masks, Ventilators and Tests
description: President Trump has delegated the authority to invoke extraordinary powers over private industry, but his administration does not seem to be using it yet.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump issued an executive order this week invoking the Defense Production Act to battle the coronavirus pandemic, but his advisers have resisted making aggressive use of the law to mobilize private industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: The Deal Not Taken
description: During one frantic week, incredible travel offers emerged, only to evaporate as soon as the reality of taking advantage of them during a pandemic was weighed.
content: For a budget traveler, it was the best of times, and the worst of times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark O'Connell
title: This Is Not the End of the World and You Are Not a Prepper
description: The prepper vision of the world is bleak and ruthless. Something better is happening now.
content: Some years ago, out of a perverse need to both mediate and exacerbate my own anxieties about the climate catastrophe and the threat it posed to the structures undergirding civilization, I got very into consuming doomsday prepper content online. I can’t tell you how many hours I put in watching YouTube videos of burly American men talking about emergency water filtration techniques and what items to put in your long-term wilderness bug-out bag, but I can tell you that it was far too many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Is Now a Good or Terrible Time to Buy a Home?
description: The coronavirus crisis has disrupted the housing market. But with rates low and sellers anxious, first-time buyers could find a silver lining.
content: Q: I’m a first-time buyer looking at one-bedrooms in Brooklyn. But now I’m not sure what to do. Interest rates are low, which is good, but the coronavirus pandemic is terrifying and the stock market is plummeting. Could now possibly be a good time to buy? What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Smith
title: Bill Smith, Master of Two Musical Worlds, Is Dead at 93
description: As Bill Smith, he was a jazz clarinetist who played with Dave Brubeck. As William O. Smith, he was a composer who pioneered unorthodox techniques for his instrument.
content: Bill Smith, a clarinetist and composer who forged collaborations with some of the pre-eminent jazz and classical artists of the 20th century, including an especially long and close alliance with the pianist Dave Brubeck, died on Feb. 29 at his home in Seattle. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Scripps National Spelling Bee Is S-U-S-P-E-N-D-E-D
description: The sponsors, who suspended the contest because of the coronavirus, did not set a new date for the finals, making it unclear whether it would take place at all.
content: The national finals of the Scripps National Spelling Bee in National Harbor, Md., have been suspended, joining a long — and growing — list of events that have been canceled because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Grieving in Self-Quarantine After a Missouri Shooting
description: “It’s all just slamming at once, and we don’t know what to do,” said a friend of 22-year-old Matthew Hicks-Morris, who was killed last weekend in a shooting at a gas station in Springfield, Mo.
content: The sequence of events is grim but familiar in cities across the United States. A mass shooting takes place. A public vigil is held. A community comes together with an outpouring of anger, sadness and solidarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The Hottest Parties in Town Are Now Online
description: As many are quarantining or socially distancing themselves to curb the spread of the coronavirus, the party has moved to social media.
content: On Friday night there was one place in the country where you could take part in a social gathering and not be afraid of spreading or contracting the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: It’s Time to Protect the 2020 Election, Too
description: Voting by mail is key to ensuring the integrity and accessibility of November’s vote.
content: There is no good time for a pandemic to hit. Still, it’s hard to imagine a more vulnerable moment than the one we find ourselves in, only months before some 130 million Americans expected to head to the polls to vote for the next president and thousands of other officeholders. The outcome of the November election could shape the contours of American politics and government for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: How You Can Help Victims of the Coronavirus Pandemic
description: From charities that support children to organizations that feed families, there is no shortage of ways to get involved.
content: The coronavirus that started in Wuhan, China, late last year has spread to at least 154 countries and killed thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Soccer Is a Habit. But Habits Can Be Broken.
description: Sports are never just sports. And it’s OK to miss them now that they’re gone, and to wonder if they’ll be the same when they return.
content: Enjoying this newsletter? Forward it to a friend, or 10, and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: ‘Astronaut’ Families Stressed by Straddling 2 Worlds: China and Canada
description: Transnational migrants who shuttle between Vancouver and China confront loneliness, divorce and culture shock. But their children see advantages.
content: VANCOUVER — Bonnie Ye, 42, left China four years ago to marry a Vancouver man she met on a Chinese matchmaking website. Soon, her husband was shuttling between China and two homes in Vancouver, leaving her alone for long stretches to care for their young daughter. Now, the two are divorced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Alissa J. Rubin and Eric Schmitt
title: As Iran Reels, Trump Aides Clash Over Escalating Military Showdown
description: Sharp debates among top administration aides reveal divisions in how to confront Iran and its Shiite militia proxies in Iraq.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump was getting ready to declare the coronavirus a “national emergency,” but inside the White House last Thursday, a tense debate erupted among the president and his top advisers on a far different subject: whether the United States should escalate military action against Iran, a longtime American rival that has been devastated by the epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Self Made’ and ‘I See You’
description: Octavia Spencer stars in a new limited series on Netflix, while Helen Hunt appears in a gripping horror film on Amazon.
content: SELF MADE: INSPIRED BY THE LIFE OF MADAM C.J. WALKER Stream on Netflix. If you’re looking to binge-watch your way through the weekend, consider this biographical, four-part series. “Self Made” centers on Madam C.J. Walker (Octavia Spencer), a daughter of formerly enslaved sharecroppers, who became America’s first female, self-made millionaire in the early 1900s. Born Sarah Breedlove, Walker started her journey as a sales person for a black hair care entrepreneur before breaking away to make her own products. She started out by selling them door-to-door and eventually grew her brand into an empire. Loosely based on the book “On Her Own Ground,” by Walker’s great-great-granddaughter A’Lelia Bundles, the show mostly concerns her later years and charts her obstacles with racial and gender biases. Critics have said the series suffers from clumsy storytelling, but it boasts noteworthy credits: Blair Underwood and Tiffany Haddish co-star, while Kasi Lemmons, the director of the Oscar-nominated biopic “Harriet,” is a director and executive producer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: MBS: The Rise of a Saudi Prince
description: Mohammed bin Salman was the sixth son of the 25th son of a king — in short, a man seemingly destined for obscurity. It didn’t work out that way.
content: An excerpt from “MBS: The Rise to Power of Mohammed bin Salman,” a new book by the Beirut bureau chief for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: MBS: The Rise of a Saudi Prince
description: Mohammed bin Salman was the sixth son of the 25th son of a king — in short, a man seemingly destined for obscurity. It didn’t work out that way.
content: An excerpt from “MBS: The Rise to Power of Mohammed bin Salman,” a new book by the Beirut bureau chief for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Western Universities Rely on China. After the Virus, That May Not Last.
description: In Britain, the United States and Australia, the coronavirus could blow huge holes in the budgets of universities that have “become addicted to one source of income.”
content: LONDON — On Jiani Zhou’s university campus in southwestern England, the racism arrived before the coronavirus did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cross Ties
description: Will Shortz challenges us to make connections.
content: VARIETY PUZZLE — This was a new one for me, and quite challenging, although easy to explain. Will Shortz has created a series of unclued mini crossword puzzles whose entries all fit into one category. Each puzzle has a few letters to help you get going, but that’s it — coming up with a category that you can draw from to fill in each little puzzle is up to you. The presentation seems like a pen-and-paper example of the Sunday puzzles that Mr. Shortz does on NPR, which are archived and listenable if you want a little more variety action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: As Visitors Continue to Arrive, Tourist Areas Say: Stay Home
description: “Virus refugees” are still going to some vacation spots, but leaders there are asking them to reconsider.
content: Even as millions of Americans are on lockdown in their homes, some people are still traveling to vacation spots, drawn by cheap airfares, the hope of riding out the pandemic in someplace less populated, or both. In Hawaii, statistics show that arrivals, which have been trending down since late February, largely led by a steep drop in visitors from Japan, remained, as of March 16, at about 80 percent of last year’s figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Kevin Quealy
title: American Partisanship May Find Its Limits in Coronavirus
description: After initially being dismissive, Republicans are starting to move closer to matching Democrats’ level of concern.
content: After initially being dismissive, Republicans are starting to move closer to matching Democrats’ level of concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: With the Coronavirus Restrictions, Can I Travel by Car?
description: We asked experts in epidemiology and infectious diseases, who offered precautions you should take to stay safe from infection.
content: With states across the country issuing instructions for residents to stay at home to help curb the coronavirus outbreak, readers from Atlanta to Central Oregon emailed with questions about whether it is safe to travel by car. Over the phone, email and in text messages, we asked experts in epidemiology and infectious diseases for answers — and what precautions you should take, if you must hit the road, to stay safe from infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: As Crisis Deepens, Companies Hand Out Cash to Workers
description: Some large businesses are paying employees while they stay home. Others are offering bonuses to those who must keep going in.
content: A thousand dollars here, $200 there, free lunch once a week, stipends for electronic equipment: Those are some of the ways the biggest companies in the United States have come up with to help their employees get through the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Coronavirus Deaths by U.S. State and Country Over Time
description: Compare the number of deaths and their rate of increase over time in the places the virus has hit hardest so far.
content: Compare the number of deaths and their rate of increase over time in the places the virus has hit hardest so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: 1,200 Airport Workers in N.Y.C. Area Abruptly Laid Off With No Severance
description: Amid the spreading pandemic, thousands of employees of businesses in the airports around New York City may have their benefits cut off.
content: Maria Campos had worked as a waitress at La Guardia Airport for more than 30 years until Tuesday, when her career came to an abrupt halt that left her scared and empty-handed. She was ordered to turn in her airport access badge and told she would receive no severance pay and would soon run out of health insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: It’s Dangerous to Be Ruled by Fear
description: The reaction to the pandemic should not be allowed to become as dangerous as the disease itself.
content: Donald Trump’s first instinct when it came to the coronavirus was to dismiss the threat as overblown, over there, and “totally under control.” His second was to use the pandemic as an opportunity to show off his world-historical leadership skills by treating the virus as a threat on par with World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: It’s Dangerous to Be Ruled by Fear
description: The reaction to the pandemic should not be allowed to become as dangerous as the disease itself.
content: Donald Trump’s first instinct when it came to the coronavirus was to dismiss the threat as overblown, over there, and “totally under control.” His second was to use the pandemic as an opportunity to show off his world-historical leadership skills by treating the virus as a threat on par with World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Storm Expected to Bring Snow to the Northeast on Monday
description: The first few days of spring will see a mix of rain and snow from coast to coast, forecasters said.
content: Winter may be officially over but the first few days of spring are expected to bring storms with a mix of rain and snow from coast to coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: How Coronavirus-Weary Americans Are Seeking Joy
description: The spread of the virus has cut Americans off from each other, but some are using the opportunity to enjoy more simple pleasures.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE — Americans were sunning themselves on beaches just days ago. They were sipping cocktails at bars. They were cheering on sports teams and working out at the gym. They were chasing culture at museums and cutting a rug at clubs. They were trying to get lucky in Vegas, and romping through Disneyland, the Happiest Place on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Lessons From My Grandma on Art, Sex and Life
description: She was unfailingly true to herself at a time when many doors were closed to women.
content: My father once asked his mother, the artist Annette Nancarrow, what she thought of Leon Trotsky. It wasn’t a political question. He just wanted her impression of the exiled Bolshevik, whom she had first met in Mexico City in the late 1930s, in the studio of her close friend (and, my father suspected, future lover) Diego Rivera.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 23 Easy Recipes for Distractibaking
description: No-knead bread, Katharine Hepburn’s brownies, and more recipes.
content: If you’re stuck inside, you’ll need an approachable project. You could bake Mark Bittman’s lemon-almond tart (above), our recipe for Katharine Hepburn’s brownies, Nutella banana bread, or any of the recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne-Marie Slaughter
title: Forget the Trump Administration. America Will Save America.
description: The federal government bungled its response to the coronavirus. But leaders around the country give us reason to hope.
content: South Korea mobilized health care companies to make coronavirus tests in late January, when the country had only four cases. Soon, 10,000 Koreans a day were being tested, and now new infections are dropping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Kelton
title: Stephanie Kelton: Just Use ‘the Computer’ to Give People More Money
description: Congress has all the firepower it needs. It just needs to send spending instructions to the Federal Reserve, as it always does.
content: To stem the tide of coronavirus transmission — or “flatten the curve” — Americans have been encouraged to “socially distance” or shelter in place. As a result, our service-based economy, which relies on consumer spending, has seen demand dwindle and commerce grind to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Kenny Rogers, Who Brought Country Music to a Pop Audience, Dies at 81
description: One of the first country artists to sell out arenas, Mr. Rogers sold more than 100 million records in a career that spanned decades.
content: Kenny Rogers, a prolific singer who played a major role in expanding the audience for country music in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Friday at his home in Sandy Springs, Ga. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Coronavirus Recession Looms, Its Course ‘Unrecognizable’
description: The U.S. economic outlook darkens daily, with millions facing unemployment and businesses in a steep decline.
content: The American economy is facing a plunge into uncharted waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Used to Meeting Challenges With Bluster and Force, Trump Confronts a Crisis Unlike Any Before
description: The ways he dealt with crises in his business, real estate and even his personal life prove jarring as he leads the government’s response to a pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — During his campaign for the White House in 2016, President Trump’s advisers briefly tried to run through with him how he would address a large-scale disaster if he won. What, for instance, would he have done during Hurricane Katrina?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Andrew Jacobs, Vanessa Friedman and Michael Rothfeld
title: Governments and Companies Race to Make Masks Vital to Virus Fight
description: President Trump resists using emergency powers to compel production, saying companies will voluntarily provide much-needed protective gear.
content: President Trump on Saturday sought to assure an anxious American public that help was on the way to overwhelmed hospitals, and that private companies had agreed to provide desperately needed medical supplies to fight the fast-spreading coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Al Qaeda Branch in Somalia Threatens Americans in East Africa — and Even the U.S.
description: Several ominous signs indicate that the Qaeda affiliate, the Shabab, is seeking to expand its lethal mayhem well beyond its home base, and attack Americans wherever it can.
content: Al Qaeda’s branch in Somalia, the terrorist group’s largest and most active global affiliate, has issued specific new threats against Americans in East Africa and even the United States, U.S. commandos, counterterrorism officials and intelligence analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Eerie Streetscapes Are Stripped of Commerce
description: With tight restrictions in place, the city offered scenes that might follow a blizzard, overlaid on a sunny spring Saturday.
content: Everywhere, gates lowered. Bar stools stacked upside down. The boutiques of Soho, the specialty shops of Greenwich Village — for chess, for board games, for records — all locked away and dark. Little Italy’s signature sidewalk tables for alfresco dining had been hauled inside, leaving Mulberry Street just like any other street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Push for Cash in Rescue Package Came From Unlikely Source: Conservatives
description: Republicans are making direct aid to individuals and families a centerpiece of a relief plan to respond to the coronavirus crisis.
content: WASHINGTON — The idea to funnel cash directly to millions of Americans to help them weather the economic disaster ravaging the globe amid the coronavirus pandemic got its jump-start not from the liberal left, but from a more unlikely source: the most conservative reaches of the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslye Davis and Yousur Al-Hlou
title: ‘Everything Is Uncharted’: New Yorkers Confront Life Amid a Coronavirus Shutdown
description: With restrictions tightened on businesses and daily activity, residents are grappling with uncertainty about resources, health care and their paychecks.
content: With restrictions tightened on businesses and daily activity, residents are grappling with uncertainty about resources, health care and their paychecks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz, Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy, Pandemic’s New Epicenter, Has Lessons for the World
description: The country’s experience shows that steps to isolate the coronavirus and limit people’s movement need to be put in place early, with absolute clarity, then strictly enforced.
content: ROME — As Italy’s coronavirus infections ticked above 400 cases and deaths hit the double digits, the leader of the governing Democratic Party posted a picture of himself clinking glasses for “an aperitivo in Milan,” urging people “not to change our habits.”
source.name: The New York Times
